newsitem.title: CANADA: Canada bonds end stronger, outperform on CPI data.
newsitem.headline: Canada bonds end stronger, outperform on CPI data.

text.p: Canadian bonds closed stronger on Tuesday, sharply outperforming their U.S. counterparts, amid weaker-than-expected inflation data and expectations of a Bank of Canada rate cut, analysts said.
"The story continues to be unequivocally positive in Canada," said Anita Lauria, an economist with Salomon Brothers. "Today we just got the latest installment in that trend."
Canada's 30-year benchmark bond rose C$0.50 to C$110.90 to yield 7.083 percent. The U.S. 30-year benchmark fell 18/32 to yield 6.85 percent.
The spread between the benchmark bonds narrowed to an 11-year low of 23 basis points from 32 basis points at Monday's close.

Canada's unadjusted September consumer price index less food and energy prices, the so-called core CPI, rose just 1.2 percent year-on-year, Statistics Canada said Tuesday. Economists had forecast core CPI of 1.3 percent.

The report shows inflation is near the bottom of the Bank's 1.0-3.0 percent target range. Dealers said the report, combined with weak retail sales data on Monday, has led many to conclude the Bank of Canada will soon cut rates.
Canadian T-bill prices strengthened following the CPI data, as the market priced in another cut by the Bank of Canada, dealers said.
"Evidence today told us there's really no price pressures whatsoever in Canada," said Lauria. "Another easing could come at any time."
In other prices, the Government of Canada 7.0 percent of 2006 rose C$0.24 to C$104.20 to yield 6.427 percent. The U.S. 10-year benchmark fell 12/32 to yield 6.57 percent.
The negative spread between the 10-year bonds widened to 14 basis points from 6 basis points at Monday's close.
Canada's 10-year bond on Monday closed with a yield below the U.S. bond for the first time since 1985.
The three-month cash bill traded at 3.21 percent against the U.S. three-month bill at 5.12 percent.
